Posted By: stygimoloch (6/23/2009 11:16:26 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: Bears with drawbacks are usually bad, but you have to remember this little puppy is from Odyssey, where graveyards mattered. In that set, being able to just sacrifice your early attacker for Threshold fodder when you no longer need it might be important. Still, not a good card: there are plenty of ways to kill your own creatures without resorting to "Attack with me or I die" as a strategy. And really, you're going to attack into overwhelming power if you want it dead anyway, and might get damage through if your opponent thinks you're up to something, so what's the point?
posts.html:
Bears with drawbacks are usually bad, but you have to remember this little puppy is from Odyssey, where graveyards mattered. Still, not a good card: there are plenty of ways to kill your own creatures without resorting to "Attack with me or I die" as a strategy. And really, you're going to attack into overwhelming power if you want it dead anyway, and might get damage through if your opponent thinks you're up to something, so what's the point?

posts.post_content: i don't understand the balance of the cards in this hound cycle. why do green and white get 2/2 creatures for 2 with often amazing abilities ([wild mongrel](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=wild mongrel)) and the other colors have absolutely awful drawbacks? ([phantom whelp](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=phantom whelp) is possibly one of the worst blue creatures ever)
